factoid: Natásha's mother asked Natásha why Natásha was wandering about like an outcast.
Natásha's mother asked Natásha what Natásha wanted.
Natásha said Natásha wanted him.
Natásha had glittering eyes and no sign of a smile.
The countess lifted her head and looked attentively at Natásha.
Natásha told the countess not to look at Natásha.
Natásha said Natásha would cry directly.
The countess told Natásha to sit down with Natásha a little.
Natásha said Natásha wanted him and asked why Natásha should be wasted like this.
Natásha's voice broke, tears gushed from Natásha's eyes, Natásha turned quickly to hide them, and Natásha left the room.
Natásha passed into the sitting room, stood there thinking for a while, and then went into the maids’ room.
An old maidservant was grumbling at a young girl who had just run in through the cold from the serfs’ quarters.
The old maidservant said stop playing—there’s a time for everything.
Natásha told Kondrátevna to let the young girl alone.
Natásha told Mavrúshka to go.
Natásha released Mavrúshka.
Natásha crossed the dancing hall and went to the vestibule.
An old footman and two young footmen were playing cards in the vestibule.
They broke off and rose as Natásha entered.
Natásha thought what Natásha could do with the footmen.
Natásha asked Nikíta to go to the yard and fetch a fowl, a cock.
Natásha told Misha to bring some oats.
Misha asked if just a few oats.
The old footman urged Misha to go quickly.
Natásha told Theodore to get a piece of chalk.
Natásha told the footmen to set a samovar, though it was not tea time.
Fóka was the most ill-tempered person in the house.
Natásha liked to test Natásha's power over the footman.
Fóka asked whether the samovar was really wanted.
Fóka pretended to frown at Natásha.
No one in the house sent people about or gave them as much trouble as Natásha did.
Natásha could not see people unconcernedly, but had to send them on some errand.
Natásha seemed to be trying whether any of them would get angry or sulky with Natásha.
The serfs fulfilled no one’s orders so readily as they did Natásha’s.
Natásha thought what Natásha could do and where Natásha could go as Natásha went slowly along the passage.
Natásha asked the buffoon what sort of children Natásha should have.
The buffoon answered that Natásha should have fleas, crickets, grasshoppers.
Natásha said O Lord, O Lord, it's always the same, and asked where Natásha should go and what Natásha should do with herself.
Natásha ran quickly upstairs to see Vogel and his wife who lived on the upper story.
Two governesses were sitting with the Vogels at a table with plates of raisins, walnuts, and almonds.
The governesses were discussing whether it was cheaper to live in Moscow or Odessa.
Natásha sat down, listened to their talk with a serious and thoughtful air, and then got up again.
Natásha said 'The island of Madagascar' and repeated each syllable distinctly.
Madame Schoss asked Natásha what Natásha was saying, but Natásha did not reply and went out of the room.
Natásha’s brother Pétya was upstairs too.
Pétya was preparing fireworks to let off that night.
Natásha called Pétya and asked him to carry her downstairs.
Pétya ran up and offered Natásha his back.
Natásha jumped on Pétya’s back, putting Natásha's arms round his neck, and he pranced along with her.
Natásha said no, don’t, the island of Madagascar, and jumped off Pétya’s back to go downstairs.
